channel.title: Linux RS Private Server
channel.description: Okay how can I run a private server on Linux, and do you have precompiled server files, because I don't want to have to put a Javac on my VPS, because it only has like 200MB of it's 8GB capacity left. So pressed for space.

item.title: Linux RS Private Server
item.dc:creator: @papetowe papetowe
item.description:
@papetowe wrote:

frank_:

wow, you are using linux but dont know how to install sun java?

Nowadays, linux is easy to install without any pervious knowledge it.

(ubuntu)

Read full topic

item.title: Linux RS Private Server
item.dc:creator: @Taylor Taylor
item.description:
@Taylor wrote:

Instructions:

Download JDK 5.0 Update 8: http://java.sun.com/javase/downloads/index.jsp pick Linux self-extracting file. Download it to your Desktop.

cd Desktop sudo aptitude install build-essential sudo aptitude install fakeroot java-package java-common fakeroot make-jpkg jre-1_5_0_08-linux-i586.bin sudo dpkg -i sun-j2re1.5_1.5.0+update08_i386.deb sudo update-alternatives --config java

When asking for which version you want to choose pick;

3        /usr/lib/j2sdk1.5-sun/bin/java

Testing;

java -version

Making a Launcher for Java Control Center;

sudo gedit /usr/share/applications/java.desktop

fill in;

[Desktop Entry]
Name=Java Control Center
Comment=Java Options & Configuration.
Exec=sh /usr/lib/j2re1.5-sun/bin/ControlPanel
Icon=
Terminal=false
Type=Application
Categories=Application;System;

Save and exit.
You can find it now under Applications tab —> System Tools.

Read full topic

item.title: Linux RS Private Server
item.dc:creator: @Zach1188 Zach1188
item.description:
@Zach1188 wrote:

On another topic

a private server & jdk will easily fit on 200mb… and theres no difference running java whether it be windows or linux, just you need a different jvm, but the class files are the same, only reason i dont use linux is cause theres no drivers for my network card >_>

[offtopic] Use K/X/Ubuntu, the drivers should run out of the box. [/offtopic]

@Saurumon2: Just remember, Java is multi-platform.

Read full topic
